comment_text: The grape has unfortunately been declared dead, due to the large cavity left by an unknown impalement.

I would not eat that grape

One day, probably soon, the vast majority of surgery will be done by fully autonomous robots. I'm amazed how much this idea seems to terrify people. I trust a robotic surgeon more than a robotic car.

There is also a MASSIVE financial benefit from robotic surgery because once a robot can perform an operation, that robot can be mass-produced. Robots are getting more sophisticated and precise while humans aren't improving at all.

Computers don't make mistakes - people do. Computers don't get tired, or distracted, and they can be programmed to accommodate any scenario that has ever been recorded in human history. Computers have no ego, or any other impediment to performing its task as well as possible.

I figure surgery will be a human vocation for about one more generation because it will save hundreds of billions (maybe trillions globally).

Also, robots are 100 percent sterile, which is impossible with humans.

The cost of ONE minimally-invasive temporal lobe scar removal operation is at least $300,000. Let's say a surgical robot costs $3 million. It pays for itself in ten operations. This is a no-brainer (so to speak).
I want to see a whole channel about this!
